estimation_measure: Existential catastrophe from “other anthropogenic risks” (which includes but is not limited to nanotechnology) by 2120
other_notes: See this post for some commentary: https://forum.effectivealtruism.org/posts/Z5KZ2cui8WDjyF6gJ/my-thoughts-on-toby-ord-s-existential-risk-estimates#_Unforeseen__and__other__anthropogenic_risks__Surprisingly_risky_

estimation_measure: "Infinite impact" from nanotechnology within the next 100 years, which "refers to the state where civilization collapses and does not recover, or a situation where all human life ends" (according to Beard et al.)
source: Pamlin, D. & Armstrong, S. (2015). Global Challenges: 12 Risks that Threaten Human Civilisation, Global Challenges Foundation.

estimation_measure: Human extinction by 2100 as a result of “molecular nanotech weapons”
other_notes: This is the median. Beard et al.'s appendix says "Note that for these predictions no time frame was given." I think that that's incorrect, based on phrasings in the original source, but I'm not certain.

estimation_measure: Human extinction by 2100 as a result of “the single biggest nanotech accident”
other_notes: This is the median. Beard et al.'s appendix says "Note that for these predictions no time frame was given." I think that that's incorrect, based on phrasings in the original source, but I'm not certain.

estimation_measure: Existential catastrophe from nuclear war by 2120
Human extinction by 2100 as a result of “nuclear wars”
other_notes: This is the median. Beard et al.'s appendix says "Note that for these predictions no time frame was given." I think that that's incorrect, based on phrasings in the original source, but I'm not certain.

estimation_measure: Human extinction by 2100 as a result of “acts of nuclear terrorism”
other_notes: This is the median. Beard et al.'s appendix says "Note that for these predictions no time frame was given." I think that that's incorrect, based on phrasings in the original source, but I'm not certain.

estimation_measure: The chance of “a civilization-ending nuclear war” (or one that causes extinction?) in “the next century”
other_notes: It’s also worth noting that Todd uses the phrases “permanently end civilization” and “civilization-ending nuclear war” here, but the article and some other estimates in it are focused on extinction, rather than other scenarios like permanent collapse. I’m thus not sure precisely what scenarios Todd is estimating (or broadly discussing) the risk of.

estimation_measure: “Reduction in far future potential per year from [the risk of a?] full scale nuclear war”
other_notes: There's some relevant info/discussion in these three sources (especially the first two): https://forum.effectivealtruism.org/posts/CcNY4MrT5QstNh4r7/cost-effectiveness-of-foods-for-global-catastrophes-even https://80000hours.org/podcast/episodes/david-denkenberger-allfed-and-feeding-everyone-no-matter-what/ https://forum.effectivealtruism.org/posts/D8t5TtSemqcGa4g7Y/my-open-for-feedback-donation-plans#1__Should_I_donate_to_ALLFED_ Denkenberger's model includes an estimate of the annual probability of nuclear war, based on Barrett 2013, and an estimate of the impacts a nuclear war would have if it occurred, based on a survey he sent to “31 GCR researchers”, which “got seven responses (including [Denkenberger himself])”. He multiplies these figures together to get the “Reduction in far future potential per year from full scale nuclear war” (which I believe should say “from the risk of a full scale nuclear war”). The estimate for that is ~0.29%.

estimation_measure: “Reduction in far future potential per year from [the risk of a?] full scale nuclear war”
The risk of extinction due to the consequences of nuclear war, or as a result of a ‘Doomsday machine’, in the 21st century
other_notes: Beard et al.'s appendix makes it seem somewhat unclear what this is about or how to interpret. See that appendix for details.
source: Turchin, A. V. (2008) Structure of the global catastrophe. Risks of human extinction in the XXI century lulu.com

estimation_measure: "Infinite impact" from nuclear war within the next 100 years, which "refers to the state where civilization collapses and does not recover, or a situation where all human life ends" (according to Beard et al.)
source: Pamlin, D. & Armstrong, S. (2015). Global Challenges: 12 Risks that Threaten Human Civilisation, Global Challenges Foundation.
